did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: Hoover Institution on War, Revolution, and Peace

did.abstract: Writings, correspondence, notes, memoranda, and printed matter, relating to economic conditions in the United States, laissez-faire and conservative political thought, right-to-work issues, and political conditions in southern Africa, especially Zimbabwe and South Africa.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

chronitem.event: Member, Board of Editors, Fortune magazine
Author, The Lives of Winston Churchill

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of John Davenport were acquired by the Hoover Institution from his widow, Marie Davenport, in 1999. They relate mainly to his career as economist, author, and journalist from 1927 until his death in 1987. His position as editor at Barron's weekly and Fortune provided a fruitful venue for his widely read writings.

The bulk of the collection consists of holographs, typescripts, and printed copies of these writings. They relate mainly to American and international economic policy, economic planning, the gold standard, labor unions, labor law, Rhodesia, South Africa, and welfare economics. Included are many speeches on the same topics.

Of significant importance is Davenport's correspondence with prominent economists and politicians, such as Milton Friedman, Friedrich von Hayek, Jesse Helms, Henry Kissinger, and Karl von Wiegand, which reflects his life-long interest in the economy and political life of the United States.

The Mont Pèlerin Society, the National Right to Work Committee, and the National Right to Work Legal Defense Committee files are smaller but equally important parts of the collection. The Mont Pèlerin Society file consists of materials on meetings, newsletters, and Davenport's speeches and writings as a member of the Society. The National Right to Work Committee and the National Right to Work Legal Defense Committee files consist of materials relating to the labor question in the United States and reflect Davenport's contribution to both organizations.

Of special note in the Subject File is material relating to Rhodesia and South Africa. The Rhodesian materials reflect the economic and political conditions before the advent of Zimbabwe. The South African materials provide an especially interesting source for the study of economic policy and apartheid.

controlaccess.head: Indexing Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the repository's online public access catalog.

scopecontent.p: Address books, family correspondence, mailing lists, and miscellany, arranged alphabetically by physical form.
Letters sent and received, arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent.
Handwritten and typewritten drafts, typescripts, manuscripts, speech transcripts, printed copies, notes and related materials, arranged chronologically by title.
Correspondence, minutes of meetings, newsletters, and speeches and writings by J. Davenport, arranged alphabetically by physical form.

did.unittitle: National Right to Work Legal Defense Foundation File, 1969-1987.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, reports, financial information, news releases and other material relating to the operations of the National Right to Work Legal Defense Foundation, arranged alphabetically by subject.

did.unittitle: National Right to Work Committee File, 1971-1987.

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, news releases, newsletters, and printed matter relating to operations of the National Right to Work Committee, arranged alphabetically by subject.
Correspondence, memoranda, reports, printed matter and other material, collected by J. Davenport and relating to various subjects, arranged alphabetically by subject.
Articles by various individuals, arranged alphabetically by name of author.
